required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Self-Propelled Versus Standard Percutaneous Endoscopic Gastrojejunostomy(PEG-J); RCT
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison Outcomes and Complications of Self-Propelled vs. Standard Percutaneous Endoscopic Gastrojejunostomy (PEG-J); a Randomized Single Blind Clinical Trial

brief_summary.textblock: Our main hypothesis is that self-propelled Percutaneous Endoscopic Gastrojejunostomy tube (PEG-J) that has a balloon on it's tip is associated with lower J-tube retrograde migration rate, and lower rates of short- and long-term complications when compared to standard PEGJ feeding tubes.

clinical_study.why_stopped: Study was terminated prematurely as costs incurred were more than the available funds.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With PEG-J Tube Migration
primary_outcome.time_frame: From date of placement up to 4 weeks
primary_outcome.description: Number of participants in whom migration was assessed by X-ray at 4 weeks post-intervention.

secondary_outcome.measure: Repeat Endoscopy for Feeding Tube Placement Due to Retrograde Tube Migration
secondary_outcome.description: Patiens who will have retrograde PEG-J tube migration will get repeat endoscopy for PEG-J tube placement
Determine tube patency which is defined as time period between tube placement and need for re-intervention.
Success of tube placement in the desired location as determined endoscopically.
Time required from introduction of the upper endoscope until placement of the feeding tube.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Repeat Endoscopy for Tube Replacement
secondary_outcome.description: If repeate endocopy and tube placement are needed due to clogging or retrograde migration
Scored by the endoscopist on a 10-point Visual Analogue Scale with zero being "without difficulty" and 10 being "maximum difficulty". The lower the score, the better the outcome.

secondary_outcome.measure: Gastrointestinal Quality of Life Index (GIQLI) Score
secondary_outcome.description: Gastrointestinal Quality of Life Index (GIQLI) score ranging from 0 (worst quality of life possible with severe digestive symptoms) to 144 (optimal quality of life without symptoms

Short-term complications will include stomal (Infection, erythema, bleeding, pain and secretion, etc) and tube (Clotting, dislocation, defect, aspiration, etc) complications detected in the first week.

Long-term complications will include stomal (Infection, erythema, bleeding, pain, secretion, abscess, etc) and tube (Clotting, dislocation, defect and aspiration, etc) complications detected more than one week after intervention.

Cost will be determined according to Medicare reimbursement of billed CPT codes. The cost of all related follow-up procedures will be included (e.g. cost of standard PEGJ in case of failed Self-propelled PEGJ feeding tube, cost of managing complications, cost of re-intervention in case of tube dysfunction, etc)

arm_group.description: Patients in this arm will receive self-propelled balloon PEGJ tube.
Patients in this arm will receive the standard commercially availabel PEGJ tube.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Consecutive adult patients (18-80 years of age) with need for post-pyloric feeding (patients unable to eat due to stroke, intubated patients with respiratory failure, patients with acute pancreatitis, etc).
- Ability to give informed consent.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Unable to give informed consent
- Pregnant or breastfeeding women (all women of child-bearing age will undergo urine pregnancy testing)
- Acute gastrointestinal bleeding
- Coagulopathy defined by prothrombin time < 50% of control; PTT > 50 sec, or INR > 1.5), on chronic anticoagulation, or platelet count <50,000
- Inability to tolerate sedated upper endoscopy due to cardio-pulmonary instability or other contraindication to endoscopy
- Cirrhosis with portal hypertension, varices, and/or ascites
- Allergy to egg

overall_official.affiliation: Johns Hopkins Hospital Department of Gastroenterology

reference.citation: Kim KJ, Victor D, Stein E, Valeshabad AK, Saxena P, Singh VK, Lennon AM, Clarke JO, Khashab MA. A novel ballooned-tip percutaneous endoscopic gastrojejunostomy tube: a pilot study. Gastrointest Endosc. 2013 Jul;78(1):154-7. doi: 10.1016/j.gie.2013.03.005. Epub 2013 Apr 24.

responsible_party.investigator_title: Assistant Professor of Medicine; Director of Therapeutic Endoscopy

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Patients were enrolled between 7/1/13 and 4/14/14 in an academic tertiary center

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
